anatomical location body part affected: The diarthrodial joints, including cartilage, joint capsule, synovial membrane, synovial fluid, bursa, tendon, muscle, and bone; rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a systemic disease that ultimately affects the entire person
description: RA is a chronic, inflammatory, systemic disease that most prominently affects the diarthrodial joints (freely mobile joints held together by a joint capsule; also called synovial joints).(1,2) In RA, the immune system attacks the body’s own tissues (specifically the synovial membrane, a thin membrane that lines the joints) rather than foreign cells such as bacteria or viruses.(3) This causes synovitis and tenosynovitis, resulting in both joint pain and systemic inflammation.(1,4) Individuals with RA often experience intermittent periods of intense disease activity, referred to as flares, followed by periods of remission with no disease activity or symptoms, and is variable with regard to onset and progression.(1,4) For others the disease is continuously active and gets worse over time.(1) Clinically distinguishing features of RA include morning stiffness that lasts for over 1 hour and the gel phenomenon (stiffness that occurs after long periods of sitting or inactivity)(1,4)

RA typically involves 3 or more joints, but in 2010 the American College of Rheumatology and the European League Against Rheumatism updated guidelines aimed at identifying RA in patients with synovitis in at least one joint in the absence of an alternative diagnosis to explain the synovitis, and a score of at least 6 (of the possible 10) from 4 domains. These 4 domains include(42) –the number and site(s) of involved joint –serologic abnormalities (presence of rheumatoid factor or anti-citrullinatedpeptide/protein  antibody) –elevations of inflammatory markers (erythrocyte sedimentation rate and/or C-reactive protein [CRP]) –the duration of symptoms
The 2010 diagnosis criteria allowfor early diagnosis of RA(42)
RA is a systemic disease and can affect extraarticular body systems such as the heart, pulmonary and GI systems, and skin(1,4)

The course of RA in any given patient can vary significantly; there are at least three known disease courses: –Monocyclic: having one episode that ends within 2 to 5 years of initial diagnosis with no recurrence; typically, monocyclic cases occur if RA is diagnosed very early in the course of the disease and/or the patient has aggressive treatment(21) –Polycyclic: symptoms and levels of disease activity fluctuate over the course of the patient’s lifetime(21)  –Progressive: the symptoms of RA become increasingly severe, and the course of the disease is unremitting(21)

contraindications precautions to test: Use of resistance exercises is contraindicated in acute and chronic-active  stages of RA; resistance can damage inflamed tissue and joints(4)
Modification of active/passive ROM testing and muscle strength testing might be necessary for joints exhibiting signs of acute inflammation(4)
Resistive manual muscle testing (MMT) is contraindicated during acute flares(4)
The therapist should be gentle and move slowly while handling painful swollen joints(4)
Palpation should be gentle and repeated as few times as possible(4)
Proceed with caution when examining, palpating, or manipulating joints with skin that is fragile as a result of RA or medication side effects(4)
Patient should be positioned comfortably and fully supported during examination, and testing should be performed with as few position changes as possible(4)
Activity should stop when the patient feels pain, fatigue, or discomfort(4)
Physician’s orders and protocol should be followed at all times(4)
Vigorous stretching and vigorous manipulative techniques are contraindicated(4)

Evaluations for patients with RA should utilize a client-centered approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(4,28) –A client-centered  approach includes the following principles:  -The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about their occupational functioning(4) -The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes(4) -The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent(4) -Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, interests, etc.(4) -When the patient can define the problems that they would like to work on, the patient also becomes a problem solver(4) -The patient should evaluate their own performance and set personal goals(4)

pathogenesis: The clinical presentation of RA varies significantly; both genetic and environmental factors will affect the progression,extent, and pattern of the disease within a specific patient(1)

As RA progresses, the patient’s synovial membrane changes into disorganized lymphoid granulation tissue(1)–Both resident and infiltrating cells contribute to hyperplasia of the synovial membrane and erosion of the cartilage or bonein RA(1)

The patient’s immune system begins to attack the synovial membrane of the joints, leading to inflammation(1)–The inflammation leads to increased heat, swelling, pain, and redness and decreased ROM in the affected joint(1)–As this inflammation continues, the synovial membrane cells multiply and create a mass called pannus(1,2)–The pannus weakens and eventually destroys the underlying cartilage of the joint(1,2,4)–The joint space becomes obliterated by fibrous adhesions(1)–This entire process results in continuous tissue damage(1)
Scar tissue can form between the bone ends of the joint, resulting in permanent loss of joint function and mobility. Swellingof the joints can lead to instability(4)
risk factors: Age (can develop at any age; however, risk increases with age)(4)

Sex (higher incidence in females)(3,4,21)–In women, some factors related to reproductive and breastfeeding history have been linked to increased risk for RA(21)-Most studies related to birth history and RA have found that women who have never had a live birth have a slight tomoderately increased risk of RA-Some studies have found that RA is less common in women who breastfeed-Women with irregular menstrual cycles as well as those with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) have an increasedrisk of RA-There is mixed evidence regarding the association between use of oral contraceptives and hormone replacement therapyand RA risk

course of treatment.medical management: There is no cure for RA; however, medical treatments are available for symptom management(1,4) Patients with painful joints often delay seeking medical care for 2-4 years after symptoms first present(1) RA can be difficult to diagnose in its early stages; however, early diagnosis and treatment are essential for maximizing functional outcomes(1,3) There is no test specifically for RA; diagnosis is based on medical history, symptomatology, physical examination, and radiographic images(3,5) alleviate pain and stiffness of the joints(1,4) reduce the swelling of the joints(1,4) preserve maximal joint function and muscle strength(1,4) prevent disability and disease-related morbidity(4) minimize adverse effects of the long-term  use of medications(1,4) maintain functional status(1,4) promote normal growth and development (for children with RA)(1) physical management (including occupational and physical therapy)(1) psychosocial management(1) nutritional therapy(1) pharmacological management(1) management of comorbidities(1) Surgery for patients with RA is indicated for severely damaged joints and involves total joint replacement; knee and hip joint replacements are associated with the most positive outcomes with respect to increased function and mobility(1,4) In addition to joint replacements, surgical interventions for RA include arthrodesis (joint fusion), synovectomy (excision of diseased synovium), and tenosynovectomy (removal of diseased tendon sheaths)(4)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken as prescribed? Does the patient feel they are adequately controlling symptoms? Treatment with disease-modifying  antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) should begin as soon as a diagnosis of RA is(1,2,4) Conventional (nonbiological) DMARDsare considered the first line of therapy Methotrexate is the most common nonbiological DMARD and may be used alone or in combination with another agent depending on the degree of disease activity  Biological DMARDs include tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (TNF), abatacept, and tocilizumab Short term NSAIDs or corticosteroids may provide symptom relief during flares(1,2,4)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The overall goals of rehabilitation programs for patients with RA are reduced pain, joint protection, and improved functional status.(4) The role of the occupational therapist (OT) is to provide support and education; gather pertinent information regarding the patient’s current and prior functional status, current home environment, and living situation; and train the patient to safely, efficiently, and adequately perform ADLs/IADLs, school activities, and/or job duties as independently as possible(3,4)

prognosis: There is no cure for RA; however, treatment methods can improve symptoms and functioning in patients with RA(1) –Earlier diagnosis and development of new therapeutics appear to have ameliorated historically increased mortality in patients with RA(37) -The goal of treatment is remission or low disease activity as evaluated by a composite disease activity measure -Treatment target is achievable in approximately 75–80%  of patients, although some may require multiple treatment regimens  –When RA goes untreated, it causes significant disability and shortened life expectancy(2)

Both physical and functional outcomes are difficult to predict in patients with RA(1) –Early diagnosis and treatment of RA can slow progression of joint damage in up to 90% of patients, preventing irreversiblejoint damage and disability(37)
The onset of RA is most often gradual, but it can be abrupt as well(1)
RA is typically cyclical in nature, with exacerbations and remissions(1)

Features of RA that appear to have prognostic significance include: –the number and length of remissions(1) –the levels of RF in the blood(1) –presence of rheumatoid nodules(1,4) –the extent of bone erosion visualized radiographically at the initial evaluation(1) –sustained disease activity for more than 1 year(1)

Work disability is a frequent long-term  consequence of RA(32) –Patients with RA have a 236% higher relative prevalence of functional disability compared to age-matched  controls without RA(32) –Patients with RA lose an estimated 13.7–20.3  workdays per year(32) –RA-related  disability is associated with loss of work productivity(38) -Authors of a study (N = 150) evaluated patients with RA who experienced minor difficulties in functioning and assessed themfor presenteeism (workers’ presence on the job, but with reduced productivity due to illness or disease) -After 1 year,more RA-related  disability, poorer mental health, and health deterioration were longitudinally associated with more hours lost at work because of health limitations

treatment summary: There is some evidencethat patients with RA can benefit from occupational therapy –Authors of a 2019 narrative review examined 7 studies from 2021 to 2019 on the role of nonpharmacological interventions in the management of RA-related  fatigue. They concluded that physical activity and psychosocial interventions (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) can provide small to moderate benefit in decreasing self-reported  fatigue in patients with RA(41) –Authors of a 2017systematic review evaluated 51 evidence level 1 studies published between 2000 and 2014. Outcome measures evaluated were ability to perform ADLS, pain, fatigue, depression, self-efficacy,  and disease symptoms. Strong evidencesupported the use of aerobic exercise, resistive exercise,aquatic therapy, patient education, self-management, cognitive-behavioral  approaches, multidisciplinary approaches, and joint protection to improve outcome measures. Some evidence supported the use of dynamic exercise, tai chi, and yoga to improve outcome measures(40)  –According to the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network’s (SIGN) national clinical guideline for the management of RA, the benefits of skilled occupational therapy for patients with respect to improved QOL is clear; however, there are limited studies from which efficacy conclusions can be drawn, and evidence from RCTs is absent(19) -SIGN’s guideline emphasizes that occupational therapy should focus on: -improving ADLs, providing equipment and adaptations as necessary(19) -maximizing function and level of independence of the patient(19) -educating patients on joint protection strategies, including how to reduce strain, properly use assistive devices, utilize rest schedules and energy-conservation  techniques, and use proper exercise and splinting techniques(19) –Authors of a critical appraisal of6 systematic reviews on the efficacy of interventions used by OTs for adults with RA that were published between 2007 and 2013 reported that there was sufficient evidence to support the use of therapeutic exercise, patient education on joint protection strategies, and splinting for pain, inflammation, and grip strength. There was insufficient evidence to support the use of tai chi as an intervention for RA(23)
